description: Coined by Edmund Spenser in 1596 (“blatant beast”). Probably a variation of *blatand (Scots blaitand (“bleating”)), present participle of blate, a variation of bleat, equivalent to blate +‎ -and. See bleat.

adjectives.description: blatant (comparative more blatant, superlative most blatant)

entries.meaning: Obvious, on show; unashamed; loudly obtrusive or offensive.
examples: Synonyms: ostentatious; see also Thesaurus:gaudy, Thesaurus:obvious

entries.meaning: (archaic) Bellowing; disagreeably clamorous; sounding loudly and harshly.
